messageBody:
Greetings,
Ah... I did the google, as the paper doesn't appear to talk
about isolated tests at all. (I skimmed, as my Smalltalk
is null and void.)

I did however read the PRIOR flamewar on here about
heirarchical tests, which erupted over a similar issue,
although not clearly dealing with an external stateful
system.

I respectfully disagree, but from your responses to that one,
it's clear that we're going to disagree on this.

When testing systems, I believe that tests should be clearly
seperate, and you should test one piece of functionality at
a time.

I actually implemented the storage system for this project
using test-first, and making each one of those individual
tests pass, before moving to the next one.

If it had been one big test, I wouldn't have been able to
do that. It would never have passed until the entire
system, from front to back, worked completely.

In order to make that work, I had to use static variables
in the class. I thought that stunk, at first, but did it in
order to make it all work, and be able to test parts of
functionality as I built the system.

When the time came to test multi-threaded, that smell
became unbearable, and I hoped someone had a solution.

I understand now that this is not something the test
framework intended to address.

My apologies, I didn't intend to reignite what is apparently
a well-worn tread of flame.

We test differently, is all.

-- Morgan Schweers
